title: Change the suite FQDN
content:
To change the FQDN of the suite, you must first change it in the OMT namespace, and then change it in the suite namespace.

  • To change the FQDN in the OMT namespace, run the replaceExternalAccessHost.sh script in the OMT namespace. The replaceExternalAccessHost.sh script is located in the $CDF_HOME/scripts directory on the control plane node in an on-premises environment, or located in the OMT_External_K8s_2x.x-xxx/scripts directory on the bastion node in a managed Kubernetes environment.
     
    •  This solution requires both the original and new FQDNs of the suite to be accessible before performing the update..
    • The replaceExternalAccessHost.sh script changes only the <external access host> value in the system. All other parameters (such as API_SERVER, ETCD_ENDPOINT and CLUSTER_MGMT_ADDR in base-configmap) still use an internal host name, which you must not change manually. The design of using an internal host name for these parameters is to ensure better performance and security. 
  • To change the FQDN in the suite namespace, update the FQDN values in your customized values.yaml file and apply the changes to the suite namespace.

Prepare certificate files based on the new FQDN

  1. Regenerate new custom certificate files based on the new FQDN. For more information about how to prepare a custom certificate, see the "Related topics" section.
  2. Run the certCheck script to check the new certificate files. The script will check if the new certificate files match the new FQDN, as well as if these files and the new FQDN are valid. This script is located in the $CDF_HOME/scripts directory on the control plane node in an  on-premises environment, or located in the OMT_External_K8s_2x.x-xxx/scripts directory on the bastion node in a managed Kubernetes environment.   

    First, navigate to the $CDF_HOME/scripts directory (embedded Kubernetes) or the OMT_External_K8s_2x.x-xxx/scripts directory (managed Kubernetes). For example:

    cd $CDF_HOME/scripts

    Then, run the certCheck script:

    ./certCheck -ca <CA certificate file> -cert <server certificate file> -host <new FQDN> -key <server key> -debug

    For example:

    ./certCheck -ca $CDF_HOME/ssl/ca.crt -cert $CDF_HOME/ssl/server.crt -host mynewhost.mycompany.net -key $CDF_HOME/ssl/server.key -debug

    Make sure that the command returns a "success" result.

Prerequisites for managed Kubernetes deployments

If the suite is deployed in a managed Kubernetes environment, perform the prerequisite steps appropriate for your deployment platform.

AWS (with EKS)

Bind the new FQDN with the Application Load Balancer:

  1. Save the following file as createRecord.json: 
    {
    "Comment": "Create Alias resource record sets in Route 53",
    "Changes": [
        {
            "Action": "CREATE",
            "ResourceRecordSet": {
                "Name": "{{resource_record_set_name}}",
                "Type": "A",
                "AliasTarget": {
                    "HostedZoneId": "{{alb_hosted_zone_id}}",
                    "DNSName": "{{alb_dns_name}}",
                    "EvaluateTargetHealth": false
                }
            }
        }
    ]
}
  2. Run the following commands to specify your own values for the alias record set: 
    sed -i -e s@{{resource_record_set_name}}@${EXTERNAL_ACCESS_HOST}@g ./createRecord.json
sed -i -e s@{{alb_dns_name}}@${ALB_DNS}@g ./createRecord.json
sed -i -e s@{{alb_hosted_zone_id}}@${ALB_HOSTED_ZONE_ID}@g ./createRecord.json

    where:

    • {EXTERNAL_ACCESS_HOST} is the FQDN prepared for the Application Load Balancer.
    • {ALB_DNS} is the DNS name of the created Application Load Balancer. You can find the DNS name of the ALB on its Description tab.

    • {ALB_HOSTED_ZONE_ID} is the hosted zone ID of the created ALB. For example, Z1H1FL5HABSF5. You can find your ALB's hosted zone ID by running the following command. Replace {ALB_DNS_Name} with your actual value.

      alb_hosted_zone_id: aws elbv2 describe-load-balancers --query "LoadBalancers[?DNSName==\`${ALB_DNS_Name}\`].CanonicalHostedZoneId" --output text
  3. Update the AWS CLI by following the steps described in the AWS CLI documentation.
  4. Run the command below to create the Route 53 record set: 
    aws route53 change-resource-record-sets --hosted-zone-id ${ROUTE53_HOSTED_ZONE_ID} --change-batch file://./createRecord.json

    where {ROUTE53_HOSTED_ZONE_ID} is the hosted zone ID of your domain name. For example, Z18D5FSROUN65G. You can find your domain name's hosted zone ID by running the following command. Replace {Domain_Name} with your actual value.

    HOSTED_ZONE_ID: aws route53 list-hosted-zones-by-name --query "HostedZones[?Name==\`${Domain_Name}.\`].Id" --output text | sed s@/hostedzone/@@g
  5. Import the certificate to ACM, and replace the application load balancer certificate that's bound in the listener. To do this, follow these steps:
    1. Run the following command on the bastion node (managed Kubernetes):  
      aws acm import-certificate --certificate fileb://<server.crt> --private-key fileb://<server.key> --certificate-chain fileb://<ca.crt> --region <region>
    2. Modify the suite-ingress.yaml file that you created during the installation by changing the <certificate_arn> value with the resource name of your new certificate: 
      alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/certificate-arn: <certificate_arn>

      For information about this yaml file, see Create an Ingress for the suite.
    3. Run the following command to apply the updated YAML file: 
      kubectl apply -f suite-ingress.yaml
    4. Repeat the steps above for the port 5443 listener. 

Azure (AKS)

Follow the following procedure to replace the application gateway certificate:

Before you begin, do the following:

  1. Log in to the bastion node, and then run the following command to change the SSL certificate to PFX format.  
    openssl pkcs12 -export -out certificate.pfx -inkey server.key -in server.crt
  2. Rename your root CA certificate to .cer format. For example, change ca.crt to ca.cer. 

Then, replace the certificate as follows:

  1. Log in to the Azure portal, and navigate to your application gateway.
  2. Locate the listener for port 443, and then click Create new under Choose a certificate. Select your certificate.pfx file to upload it. 
  3. Click Backend settings, and update the http-settings for port 443 as follows:
    1. Make sure that your root CA certificate is renamed to .cer format. Replace the http-settings ssl certificate with the root CA certificate(<ca.cer>). 
    2. In the Override with specific domain name field, change the value to the new FQDN.
  4. Locate the health probe for port 443, update the Host value to the new FQDN.
  5. Repeat the steps above for port 5443. 
  6. (For port 5443 only) Check the Backend port field. It may be automatically changed to 443. If this is the case, change it back to 5443.
  7. Rebind the new FQDN with the IP address of the application gateway. 

Change FQDN

Change the FQDN in both the OMT namespace and the suite namespace.

Change FQDN in OMT namespace

Before running the script to change the FQDN, confirm you have installed the capability tools on your environment. See Enable the OMT Tools capability on a new bastion node.

To change the FQDN in OMT namespaces, see Change the external access host name of OMT cluster. 

Change FQDN in suite namespace

Use the following steps to change the FQDN in an Helm deployment

  1. [Optional] If you don't remember the path of your custom my-values.yaml file, run the following command to get your yaml file. 
    helm get values <release name> -n <suite namespace> > my-values.yaml
    Where <release name> is the ESM release name. Run the following command to get the release name: 
    helm list -n <suite namespace> | awk '{print $1}'
    Where <suite namespace> is the unique namespace of the ESM Helm chart deployment.
  2. Update FQDN and prepare the nginx server cert and key in your values yaml. 
    global:
  # Required: the 'externalAccessHost' must be set to the cluster external domain name
  externalAccessHost: "itsma.example.com
    nginx:
  nginx:
    # tls configuration
    tls:
      # The certificate encoded with base64. If empty, a self signed certificate with cn=global.externalAccessHost will be generated.
      cert:
      # The private key of the certificate, also encoded with base64
      key:
  3. Run the following command to clean up unused jobs before applying the changes.  
    kubectl get job -n <suite namespace>|grep -v NAME | awk '{print $1}'|xargs kubectl delete job -n <suite namespace>

    Where <suite namespace> is the unique namespace of the ESM Helm chart deployment.

  4. Run the following command to apply the update: 
    helm upgrade <release name> -n <suite namespace> <ESM helm chart> -f my-values.yaml

    Where 
    <ESM helm chart>  is the absolute path of the helm package.
    <release name> is the ESM release name

    For example:

    helm upgrade sma -n itsma ESM_Helm_Chart-2x.x.x/charts/esm-1.0.0+2x.x-xxx.tgz -f my-values.yaml

Reconfigure integrations with new FQDN

After changing the suite FQDN, reconfigure the following integration settings. 

Reconfigure the ALB with new FQDN on GCP

You can skip this section if your suite is not deployed on GCP.

Complete the following steps to reconfigure the Application Load Balancer (ALB) to use the new FQDN.

Recreate suite ingress

  1. Delete the old suite ingress. 
    kubectl delete ingress sma-ingress -n <suite namespace>
  2. Create a new ALB and update the <external access host> parameter to use the new FQDN. For details, see Create the suite-install-ingress YAML section of Configure GCP external application load balancer
  3. Configure the layer 7 load balancer. For details, see Configure the layer 7 load balancer section of Configure GCP external application load balancer.

Rebind ALB with new DNS record

After you recreate the suite ingress, rebind the ALB with the new DNS record. For details, see Bind the Load balancer's IP section of Configure GCP external application load balancer. 

Reconfigure the UCMDB Gateway URL for Native SACM and SAM

After changing the suite FQDN, follow the instructions in this section to reconfigure the connection for Native SACM and SAM.

If using classic UD/UCMDB

  1. Reconfigure the Service Management host name in the config.properties file of the UCMDB Gateway. For details, see the relevant steps in Install UD/UCMDB for Native SACM.
  2. Reimport the new suite certificate based on the new FQDN to the UCMDB Gateway. For details, see the relevant step in Set up a secure connection between SMA and UCMDB Gateway.

If using containerized UD/UCMDB

  1. Update the following parameters in the UCMDB my-values.yaml file by using the new Service Managem FQDN.
    Parameters and descriptions
    Parameter Required Description Example
    global.idm.idmAuthUrl Yes

    https://<smax_new_fqdn>:443/idm-service

    		 https://newsmax.example.com:443/idm-service
    global.idm.idmServiceUrl Yes

    https://<smax_new_fqdn>:443/idm-service

    For the AWS deployment, use: https://<smax_new_fqdn_for_integration_loadbalancer>:<port>/idm-service

    		 https://newsmax.example.com:443/idm-service
    cmsgateway.deployment.smax.host Yes

    <smax_new_fqdn>

    For the AWS deployment, use:

    <smax_new_fqdn_for_integration_loadbalancer>

    		 newsmax.example.com
    cmsgateway.deployment.sam.host Yes

    <smax_new_fqdn>

    For the AWS deployment, use:

    <smax_new_fqdn_for_integration_loadbalancer>

    		 newsmax.example.com
    caCertificates Yes

    <new_smax_cert_content>

    The content of the Service Management CA certificate. When using the multi-level certificate, you need to keep the certificate chain here.

    		  
  2. Run the helm upgrade command for the new values to take effect. 
    ./helm upgrade <UD/UCMDB RELEASE NAME> <UD/UCMDB CHART FILE> --namespace <UD/UCMDB NAMESPACE> -f <MODIFIED VALUES YAML FILE>

Reconfigure the UCMDB and OO download links in the Service Management UI

If you have customized these download links in the Service Management UI, reconfigure them with the new suite FQDN. 

For details, see Enable direct download of UD Probe and UCMDB Local Client from the Service Management UI and Enable direct download of OO RAS and OO Workflow Designer from the Service Management UI.

Reconfigure the Service Management integration parameters in values.yaml for OO Containerized

  1. Reconfigure the following parameters in the values.yaml file of OO Containerized based on the new suite FQDN:
    PARAMETERS AND DESCRIPTIONs
    Parameter Required Description Example
    global.smaxFqdn Yes The FQDN and port of the public load balancer for accessing Service Management. newsmax.example.com:443
    caCertificates Yes The content of the Service Management CA certificate or the content of the Database server's certificate in a base64 encoded form.   
  2. Run the helm upgrade command for the new values to take effect: 
    ./helm upgrade <OO RELEASE NAME> <OO CHART FILE> --namespace <OO NAMESPACE> -f <MODIFIED VALUES YAML FILE>
  3. Run the following command to get a list of the OO deployment names: 
    kubectl get deploy -n oo
  4. Perform a rolling restart for related OO services: 
    kubectl rollout restart deployment -namespace <OO NAMESPACE> <give every oo deployment from step 3>

Reconfigure SAML

Go to IdM Admin Portal (https://<External_Access_Host>/idm-admin), click SYSTEM SETTINGS tab, update the Entity Base URL value with new FQDN in the SAML section. You also need to download a new metadata XML file based on the new FQDN and upload it to the SAML IdP. For detailed steps, see Download metadata from the suite.

Reconfigure On-Premises Bridge

Use the following steps to reconfigure OPB.

  1. Update FQDN in the server-connection.conf file located in the <Agent_installation_directory>/product/conf folder. For example. 
    login.base.url=https\://new-fqdn.test.com\:443/auth/authentication-endpoint/authenticate/token
maas.base.url=https\://new-fqdn.test.com\:443/rest/xxxxxxxx/remoting
  2. Update the new certificates in the OPB agent. For more detailed steps, see How to import certificates into OPB on Windows and How to import certificates into OPB on Linux.
  3. Restart the On-Premises Bridge service. For more detailed steps, see Manage the On-Premises Bridge service.

Reconfigure OAuth authentication

  1. Make sure that the following setting in your existing OAuth configuration has been updated to the suite IdM URL based on the new FQDN: https://<New FQDN>/idm-service/idm/v0/oauth2.
    redirect
    Redirect URL Yes The value of redirect URL of the IdP URL for login.

    For more information about OAuth authentication, see Add OAuth authentication. 

  2. Reconfigure the new suite IdM URL on the OAuth IdP side as trusted client information. For details, see your IdP documentation. 

Reconfigure SSL certificate for Design and Deploy (DND) 

Note: This is required only if you have enabled the DND functionality. 

After changing the FQDN, perform the steps below to import the server certificate into the DND truststore.

  • Obtain the server certificate. You can obtain the server certificate by exporting it from the browser. Copy the server certificate into the NFS shared folder <global-volume>/certificate/cmp/source.

    Example: /var/vols/itom/dnd/certificate/cmp/source

  • Delete and restart DND pods by running the following commands: 
    kubectl delete -f <OMT core NFS folder>/suite-install/itsma/output/<release_version>/itom-dnd-<build_number>/yamls/itom-dnd-controller-<tenant_id>-deployment.yaml
kubectl create -f <OMT core NFS folder>/suite-install/itsma/output/<release_version>/itom-dnd-<build_number>/yamls/itom-dnd-controller-<tenant_id>-deployment.yaml

For the UCMDB-DND integration, reconfigure the UCMDB provider configurations if you are using containerized UD/UCMDB. The reconfiguration isn't required for a standalone UCMDB setup.

For detailed steps, see Configure DND-UCMDB integration.

Reconfigure Operations Orchestrations system properties

Note: This is required only if you have enabled the DND functionality. 

  1. Log in to the Agent Interface as the tenant admin.
  2. From the Main Menu, go to Run > Automation Operations > Content Management > Configuration Items .
  3. Edit the following properties:
    • CSA_REST_URI - Update the property value to reflect the new FQDN -  https://<New_FQDN>/dnd/rest. Example - https://setup.lab.net:443/dnd/rest
    • CSA_API_URI - Update the property value to reflect the new FQDN -  https://<New_FQDN>/dnd/. Example -  https://setup.lab.net:443/dnd
